title: Trump’s war with California moves to new level
text:
As he prepares to fend off a Democratic challenger in 2020, President Donald Trump is certain to continue to hold up California as a cultural outlier and in essence, a failed state. | AP Photo/Evan Vucci Trump’s war with California moves to new level

SACRAMENTO — Donald Trump wants to put the most influential state in the nation in its place.

By threatening to yank California’s prized authority to set auto-emissions standards and to intervene so that homelessness does not “destroy” Los Angeles and San Francisco, Trump this week turned up the dial on an epic power struggle with an iconically blue state where he is wildly unpopular — and which represents the fifth-largest economy in the world.

Story Continued Below

He may not win on the policy — the courts, ultimately, will decide whether Trump’s move on auto emissions will have teeth.

But as he prepares to fend off a Democratic challenger in 2020, Trump is certain to continue to hold up California — where he courted wealthy donors up and down the state this week — as a cultural outlier and in essence, a failed state.

“He’s using California as a cudgel, as an example: If the country were to move very far left the way California is, this is the society that you would have,” said Mike Madrid, a GOP strategist and frequent Trump critic based in California. “You would have really expensive energy costs. You would have the worst poverty problem in America. You would have a homelessness situation that’s completely out of control.”

Trump has taken particular glee in lashing out at Gov. Gavin Newsom, who succeeded Jerry Brown — another longtime Trump foil — in the governor’s mansion in Sacramento this past January. Trump had a field day on Twitter when Newsom announced last winter that he was refocusing California’s high-speed rail away from a promised San Francisco-to-Los Angeles leg that had been the target of conservative ire.

poster="https://static.politico.com/8f/d7/1ba9b9934517a0f82bf050297ee1/trumpadmin-ca.png" true

“When the [Trump] administration repealed the $900 million on the high speed rail, [Trump] was just ecstatic,” said a Trump administration official who added that the president “hates” Newsom. “He thinks most people who are conservatives or agree with him … [think] that California has gone off the deep end and it should just be broken off and be another country, so it's an easy target for him to direct his ire.”

“He's not going to win the electoral votes so he obviously doesn't need to cater to them, and he makes other people happy who think that California has strange ideas and values,” the official added. “It makes sense from a campaign point of view."

Conflict with California — both policy-wise and in a more purely political way — has been a hallmark of Trump’s presidency, which has featured clashes over everything from immigration to health care to environmental protections. But Trump’s biggest provocation against California has been his threat to withdraw the state’s authority under the Clean Air Act to go further than the federal government in setting pollution standards. The move has never before been attempted, although under President George W. Bush, the EPA did refuse to grant California authority for the previous round of tailpipe emissions standards.

In a series of tweets on Wednesday, the president argued revoking California's authority would allow automakers to produce more affordable vehicles, leading to "significantly more JOBS, JOBS, JOBS!"

Also on Wednesday, in what has become a routine display of defiance, California's governor stood beside Attorney General Xavier Becerra to decry the president's latest threat while vowing the state would prevail in court.

"This was a demonstrable move to assert power and dominance, an aggressive move against the state a few days before U.N. Climate Week to punctuate the point," Newsom said.

poster="http://v.politico.com/images/1155968404/201909/1920/1155968404_6087757164001_6087757933001-vs.jpg?pubId=1155968404"

Becerra, whose tenure as attorney general has been largely defined by California's much-ballyhooed "resistance" to the Trump administration, has filed dozens of lawsuits since January 2017 to defend the state's environmental and immigration policies, among others.

"Our message to those who claim to support states' rights: Don't trample on ours," Becerra said Wednesday in a thinly veiled message to Trump.

Indeed, deregulation, not states' rights, is the common theme of Trump’s environmental rollbacks, said Ann Carlson, co-director of the Emmett Institute on Climate Change and the Environment at the University of California, Los Angeles law school.

"Basically, the environmental rollbacks are not about returning power to the states," Carlson said. “The driver is not some serious embrace of federalism, it's really about deregulation.”

In recent weeks, Trump’s fixation on California’s worsening homeless epidemic has spurred concerns among elected officials who fear the president is angling to score political points by punishing liberal cities like San Francisco and Los Angeles.

While Newsom and mayors have said they would welcome more federal dollars, the most direct ways of dealing with homelessness fall to cities and counties. Reports that Trump is contemplating federal law enforcement action — bolstered this week by his advisers, who said better policing must play a role — had state and city officials warning Trump against intervening in their affairs.

Much of the high-profile legislation advanced in California’s Capitol building over the last few years has been explicitly framed as an effort to protect California’s autonomy on policing, labor rules and the environment against the federal government. Legislative leaders in California’s Democratic supermajority this year backed a “Trump insurance” bill letting California maintain more stringent regulations. Newsom has said he plans to veto it.

“We have a duty to protect California against all threats — including threats against the quality of our air, our water and our natural resources,” Assemblywoman Laura Friedman (D-Glendale) argued as the bill neared final passage last week.

California notched a major victory last summer when a federal judge threw out a Trump administration lawsuit challenging the state's new laws limiting the cooperation of state and local law enforcement with federal immigration agents — an effort to thwart an immigration crackdown.

Former U.S. Attorney General Jeff Sessions, before he was fired last year, had actually flown out to Sacramento to announce that lawsuit in person. In a tense speech to hundreds of California police officers, the former Alabama senator went so far as to invoke the Civil War, warning that "there is no secession."

The warning shot left then-Gov. Brown furious; he said the administration "was basically going to war against the state of California."

Some of the most fiery denunciations of the Trump administration’s clean air rollbacks have come from Brown, who placed climate change at the center of his final term in office.

In an interview with POLITICO on Wednesday, Brown said he does not believe “conservative values play a real role” for Trump, who “is pretty wild in his ranging over political matters” and is influenced by “some of these developers and certain kinds of people he likes to hang out with” who are indifferent to climate change.

“They’re illegitimately asserting power,” Brown said of the Trump administration, because Congress “passed a law based on evidence giving California a waiver authority. We’ve exercised that in a lawful manner and now on a whim — I might call it a rhetorical whim, and a tweet — Trump wants to do undo that. That’s not the way the Clean Air Act works, and I believe we’ll be able to prove that in a court of law.”

Trump may be making pronouncements about California while he's in the state, but he's not talking to Californians, said Thad Kousser, a political science professor at UC San Diego. "He’s using California as a contrast, as this nanny state that wants to take away your pickup truck and make you drive a Prius, as the state that wants open borders.

"He’s criticizing the idea and the ideology of California — this idea of California as a place apart," Kousser added. "That deeply resonates in other parts of the country that don’t like us, and it helps to build his political brand that he’s a courageous straight-talker who’s not afraid of anyone.”

Daniel Lippman in Washington, DC contributed to this story.
description: The president’s latest provocation against the state has been his threat to withdraw the state’s authority to set auto-emissions standards.
